message_1: How many ways are there to divide a set of 10 identical objects into 4 non-empty subsets using Stirling numbers of the second kind?
message_2:
Stirling numbers of the second kind, denoted as S(n, k), represent the number of ways to partition a set of n elements into k non-empty subsets. In this case, we want to find S(10, 4).

The formula for Stirling numbers of the second kind is:

S(n, k) = k * S(n-1, k) + S(n-1, k-1)

To find S(10, 4), we need to calculate the Stirling numbers for smaller values of n and k. We can use a table to keep track of the values:

n\k | 1   2    3    4
----------------------
1   | 1
2   | 1   1
3   | 1   3    1
4   | 1   7    6    1
5   | 1  15   25   10
6   | 1  31   90   65
7   | 1  63  301  350
8   | 1 127  966 1701
9   | 1 255 3025 7770
10  | 1 511 9330 29224

Using the formula and filling in the table, we find that S(10, 4) = 29,224. So, there are 29,224 ways to divide a set of 10 identical objects into 4 non-empty subsets using Stirling numbers of the second kind.
